resources.string: Register to one or more childs and start to follow-up their growth
You can choose a different date
This action will delete this child and every associated register permantly
There is already a register for the selected date
The easiest way to track your child\'s development from the first day of life to the age of 19! \nYou can follow one or more children at a time.
Data used for graphs were taken from WHO\'s official web page
The percentile curves graphs allow you to take better control over the development of your children, also allow you to detect trends in their growth!
Compare the measurements with the BMI percentile and height up to 19 years, weight up to 10 years, cephalometric perimeter and weight for height up to 5 years.

Growth is not only a result of nutrition but inherited factors. Ethnicity can influence growth patterns of a child, so some countries have their own curves Growth Standards. However, the curves Growth patterns of the World Health Organization (WHO) are used more frequently and are considered the standard worldwide. 


How to take measure? 

 Head circunference 


The measurement should be taken with a tape that does not stretch. Typically it has done with a flexible metal tape measure. To measure, wrap the tape tightly around the point where the head circumference is greater. Usually this happens on the forehead, one to two fingers above the eyebrows, and behind, the most prominent area the back of the head. 

During the early years of a child's life, head circumference is an important measure because indirectly it reflects the size and growth of the brain.

Length / Height 

 The length is the linear measurement of infants up to 24 months. The measures of length (instead of height) can also be taken for children between 24 and 36 months of age who are unable to stand unassisted. The length is measured with the lying child. The most accurate way of measuring length is to use a table gage length. Tables length measurement must have a fixed head and a movable foot perpendicular to the surface of the table part. To measure the child's place in the table with the head touching the fixed part. Make sure you do not have shoes or anything in the hair. An assistant can help you hold the child to keep him still and focused on the table. Straighten your legs and adjust the moving part so that the soles of the feet are still against it. The length is an important determinant of the nutritional status of a child. It is possible that the length of a child grow very slowly if you have been starved for long. 


 Weight 

 Weight is a measure taken throughout life to help determine trends and current nutritional status. The weight of an infant can be measured accurately using multiple computers. A pediatric balance plate allows weighing the lying child. These pediatric electronic scales can be fixed or sliding weights, and are accurate to 10 grams. Another option is a hanging scale, which is attached to a firm structure (eg a beam or a door frame) and child hangs in the balance with weighing pants. To take the measurement, make sure the child takes the least amount of clothes and that nobody is touching.


If not available a pediatric scale, a scale can be used for adults. Despite an adult first and then weigh the same adult with the child in her arms. Calculate the difference between the two weights to find the weight of the infant. 


The weight-for-age is an important indicator of the nutritional status of a child and may indicate long-term trends such as a weight below expectations.


The weight-length relationship, on the other hand, helps determine the current nutritional status. This is the key indicator to determine malnutrition in children.



 Body mass index (BMI) 

 The body mass index is a number that is calculated based on the weight and height of A boy or a girl. The BMI is used as a tool to identify possible weight problems for children who may Lead to health problems.

In WHO Growth Standards curves five curves are shown (Red, orange and green) corresponding to the percentiles P3, P15, P50, P85 and P97 in order from the bottom up.\n\n The central curve or 50th percentile is the mean or average. A child with normal growth typically have a growth curve approximately parallel to the average. A single point is not enough to accurately assess a child\'s growth. a number of points are needed to understand the patterns and trends of a child\'s growth over time.

Children could be considered underweight if their weight for age is below the 15th percentile. One point that falls below the 3rd percentile weight could indicate severely underweight, indicating that the child needs special care. The severely underweight can result from delayed growth, malnutrition or both. \n\n In any case if the measures fall into one of the percentiles limits is lower or higher is recommended consult your doctor about health your child.

The growth of a child is considered delayed if its length for age remains below the percentile 15th. Infants and toddlers with delayed growth may recover part growth potential if their nutrition is improved before 2 years of age. However, for children older than 2 years who are in situations of nutritional deprivation, the delay in growth could be virtually irreversible. \n\n In any case if the measures fall into one of the percentiles limits is lower or higher is recommended consult your doctor about health your child.

Children could be seen in malnutrition if your weight for height/length is below the 15th percentile. Malnutrition is a major cause of mortality for children under 5 years so a child who is assessed as [[malnourished]] requires immediate medical attention. Children who have weight for length above the 85th percentile are considered overweight and may be at risk for childhood obesity. \n\n In any case if the measures fall into one of the percentiles limits is lower or higher is recommended consult your doctor about health your child.

Children whose head circumference is below the 15th percentile could be considered microcephalic. By contrast, the macrocephaly is a condition that indicates when the head circumference is above the 85th percentile. It is important that a physician assess children that are micro or macrocephalic. It could have serious medical implications, since it is assumed that the head circumference serves as a basic indicator of brain growth. \n\n In any case if the measures fall into one of the percentiles limits is lower or higher is recommended consult your doctor about health your child.

The Body Mass Index (BMI) is a measure that associates weight and height to determine the nutritional status of an individual.


If your child's BMI is below the 15th percentile, it is considered to be underweight. 
 If your child's BMI is between the 15-85 percentiles, it is considered a healthy weight. 
 If your child's BMI is between the 85-97 percentiles, it is considered to be overweight. 
 If it is above the 97th percentile it is considered obese. 
 

In any case if the measures fall into one of the percentiles limits is lower or higher is recommended consult your doctor about health your child..
Follow your child's growth up easily with this app.
